Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of Superinfection Exclusion By An RNA Virus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: When cells infected by one virus (the primary virus) become resistant to infection by a second virus (the secondary virus), this is called "Super-Infection Exclusion" (SIE). This phenomenon occurs when the viruses belong to the same or closely related types and has been observed for viruses, some of them pathogens, that infect various kinds of organisms, including humans, animals, and plants. SIE was initially used to test the relatedness of plant viruses and subsequently developed into a protective measure. Deliberate infection with a harmless viral strain was found to protect plants from infection by related pathogenic viruses. In medical and veterinary practice, SIE was found to diminish the effectiveness of multi-component vaccines, as well as of repeated applications of virus-based vaccines to individuals with persistent infections. Thus, fundamental understanding of the mechanism of SIE will have many practical applications. In spite of its significance, however, our knowledge of the mechanism remains surprisingly incomplete.

This project aims to elucidate the mechanism of SIE in Citrus tristeza virus (CTV), a member of the Closteroviridae family, which includes the largest and most complex positive-strand RNA viruses of higher plants. CTV represents an excellent model system to study SIE at the whole organism level, because numerous isolates having distinctive genetic characteristics have been isolated. The project builds on observations suggesting that SIE operates by a unique mechanism in CTV, possibly involving two regions of the CTV genome coding for novel viral proteins. Advanced genetic tools will be combined with innovative techniques for studying protein-protein interactions and ultra-structural characterization of individual viruses. It is anticipated that the project will advance our general knowledge of the interactions between viruses and their hosts and between virus variants in the same host, as well as deepen our specific understanding of SIE in CTV.

Broder impacts: Better understanding of how virus variants interact and exclude each other is crucial to more complete understanding of the evolution of virus populations and the emergence of new viruses. Elucidation of the mechanism(s) of SIE will also contribute to the development of novel virus-based therapeutics to reduce the effects of human, animal and plant viral diseases. Education component: The investigator's laboratory is located at the Citrus Research and Education Center in Central Florida, a region with few other research institutions. The PI has established connections with local high schools (Haines City and Auburndale High schools) and the local community college - Polk State College - to identify and recruit students, including members of under-represented groups, to participate in the proposed research in significant and meaningful ways. These efforts will enhance the infrastructure for research and education in Central Florida. The research results will be broadly disseminated via publishing in the leading peer-reviewed journals and presentations at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. This project examines how virus variants exclude each other. We are using Citrus tristeza virus (CTV) as a model to study the mechanism of viral superinfection exclusion (SIE), a phenomenon that blocks secondary virus infection in a host that was pre-infected with a closely related virus variant. Earlier, we showed that SIE occurs only between isolates of the same strain of CTV, but not between isolates of different virus strains. In this work, using support from NSF, we made a number of important discoveries that markedly advanced our understanding of CTV SIE. We demonstrated that production of viral small interfering RNAs (vsiRNAs) does not determine the ability of a CTV variant to exclude another virus containing sequences homologous to those vsiRNAs, which suggests that SIE by CTV does not represent a simple case of RNA silencing, at least in the way this mechanism has been described for a number of plant viruses.  Furthermore, we showed that CTV SIE is mediated by multiple virus factors. One of them is the viral p33 protein. Lack of the functional p33 completely eliminates the ability of the virus to exclude superinfection by the same or closely related virus. Remarkably, p33 mediates SIE at the whole organism level, while it is not required for exclusion at the cellular level. Thus, SIE by CTV is operated at two levels – the cellular and the whole organism levels – by two distinct mechanisms. While p33 is required for SIE, it is not the sole determinant of this phenomenon. Another determinant of CTV SIE maps to the 5’-proximal region in the virus genome. Collectively, the data we have obtained demonstrate that SIE by CTV does not appear to be explained by mechanisms described previously for other viruses. It is a powerful virus-controlled function that completely prevents superinfection by a homologous virus from the same virus strain. Thus, SIE by CTV is likely conferred by a novel mechanism understanding of which may open up new avenues to manage virus diseases.

 

Broader impacts. Understanding of how virus variants interact and exclude each other greatly benefits interpretation of evolution of virus populations and the emergence of new viruses as well as provides a necessary foundation for the development of novel virus-based therapeutics to reduce the effect of viral diseases in the fields of medicine and agriculture. We believe that knowledge of the mechanism underlying the CTV SIE phenomenon can be further utilized for the development of new effective strategies for controlling diseases caused by this group of viruses and possibly by viruses from other taxonomic groups. From the educational standpoint, this project provided excellent opportunities of science exposure and training for raising scientists. Several undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers have been trained in multiple molecular and cell biology techniques, including cloning into a full-length cDNA clone of such a complex virus as CTV, which genome encompasses almost 20 kb. The research results were broadly disseminated via publishing in the leading peer-reviewed journals and presentations at national scientific meetings.
